article_title: Subsidies could cushion steep increase in Obamacare rates for some
article_text:
By Kevin McKenzie of The Commercial Appeal

A 56-year-old man with no health insurance, a $10-an-hour job at a cleaners and two teenagers called Felsenthal Health Insurances Services on Tuesday and received upbeat news.

"We'll be able to give the three of them a real good policy at low cost," said Eddie Felsenthal, in the Memphis-area health insurance business for more than 50 years. "It's a very good feeling."

Despite steep hikes in the cost of individual health coverage in Tennessee, federal subsidies under the Affordable Care Act still make health insurance affordable, but too few low-income consumers are aware of them, advocates say.

With the open enrollment period beginning Sunday and extending through Jan. 31 for purchasing "Obamacare" plans available on HealthCare.gov, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services this week announced that rates for a benchmark "silver" plan in Tennessee will go up 23.4 percent.

"It will have a big impact on people who don't get subsidies," said Chuck Hudspeth of Hudspeth Benefits Group, who markets his services as the "Obamacare Answer Man."

"In most cases people who get subsidies will find the subsidies increasing to offset the premium increases."

After an initial two years of some of the lowest-cost health coverage among 37 states relying on the federal government's Health Insurance Marketplace, or HealthCare.gov, rate requests filed by insurers last spring showed the rising trend in Tennessee.

BlueCross BlueShield of Tennessee asked for an average rate increase in 2016 of 36 percent, Humana more than 18 percent, Cigna about 14 percent and UnitedHealthcare more than 11 percent.

A nonprofit insurer created with federal loans, Community Health Alliance, filed for an increase of about 33 percent, but under scrutiny from regulators, won't be offering new coverage.

Felsenthal said that he and his partner, David Deaderick, are offering help signing up consumers in Tennessee, Mississippi and Arkansas. There's no cost to the consumer; independent insurance agents and brokers are paid commissions by the insurance companies that get the new customers.

The variety of factors that should be considered include which doctors, drugs and hospital systems are covered by the plans.

"The people that are really getting killed are the part-time employees," he said. They don't reach the poverty threshold, about $11,770 a year, to qualify for subsidies and Tennessee hasn't accepted federal Medicaid dollars to expand coverage for those living below the poverty level.

"We just feel like it's such a wonderful opportunity for people to get covered," Felsenthal said. "If they don't get covered, they are going to get fined."

That fine for those who can but choose not to be covered will be at least $695 for the year.

While advice about selecting plans is available from insurance industry sources, a nonprofit group, Get Covered Tenn, is using a $1.6 million federal grant to spearhead in-person assistance in Memphis, Shelby County and the 94 other counties in Tennessee.

"In most cases people who get subsidies will find the subsidies increasing to offset the premium increases."
